title: Am I allowed to use racist terms in a fictional novel I am wanting to write about slavery? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s something called “historical context” and I personally believe that it comes with certain liberties as well as certain restrictions. The most obvious restriction is that it can only safeguard you in the event what you are writing is actually historical fiction. (I mean, historical fact works too, but you said this was a fictional novel). That means it takes place in the past and is to some extent historically accurate (by no means does it have to be TOTALLY accurate, people fudge up history in fiction all the time.) However, historical context can still be offensive if you use it the wrong way or if your setting/culture/race you are talking about is different/views things differently than the context you are using. For example, I am writing a book myself that takes place in Victorian Era England. Back then, black people in virtually all English speaking parts of the world were referred to as Negroes. However, the connotations of that word back in those days wasn’t nearly as hostile or offensive as it is taken to be now. In England, for instance, it was just a word for coloured people. When it fell out of favour in the 1880’s, no one missed it because in England, slavery had been abolished for a good 30 years prior to the American Civil War. So in England, at the time, using the word Negro to reference a black man wasn’t seen as particularly offensive unless you used it that way. (which hardly ever happened except with older families and generations; however, black people were fairly uncommon in England, so they often got stares or almost-innocent people asking what a Negro was doing in England — not in the sense of “get out of our country” but “why the hell are you here, we never see your kind” type sense. Cultural relations. They’re important.). In America, in the same time period, the Civil War was happening. So a lot more cultural sensitivity to the word Negro. If, for example, a pageboy called out on a black man asking the same as above, (“what are you doing in XYZ?”) it would be taken to be “you aren’t welcome here” as opposed to “Where the hell did you come from?”. Again, cultural relations. But by and large, for nobility in particular, it was strangely okay to call a black person a Negro, so long as it wasn’t used in a name-calling or derogatory way. For the upper class especially, the word Negro was pretty much just that — a word. Assuming you are writing about a story in America, historical context does give you a lot of wiggle room for derogatory language, simply because that’s how people talked back then. BUT I do have one caveat: The word Nigger has NEVER been a non-derogatory or non - insulting word, in either America or England. Historical context does give you the slightest bit of wiggle room because there was racism going on all over the place during that time period and everybody was calling everybody a Nigger at some point or the next. In America, the black people and native americans got the brunt of the insulting word. In England it was Indians. BUT I would use it very cautiously or very sparsely, for it always has been and always will be a pretty offensive word.

Am I allowed to use racist terms in a fictional novel I am wanting to write about slavery? Of course. Especially if writing dialogue, or from the perspective of a character who is racist. Now, I’m going to go with “Racism Lite”TM, because I don’t want a BNBR hit, so bear with me. But lets say you’re writing dialog. Johnathan: “William my friend, I must beg you for a favor.” William: “Of course, what do you need?” Johnathan: “You see, its nearly time to bring in the harvest, and a goodly number of my negros have become too ill to work. I’m afraid the weather will set in and much of the harvest will spoil before they are well again. I was hoping I might borrow some of yours.” William: “I’m sorry to hear that! That is quite the calamity. I’ll tell you what. I’ll have them harvest my fields as quickly as possible, and when most of the harvest is in, I’ll send some to you to help. That way, even if they become ill, we won’t both lose the year’s crop. But you’ll have to house and feed them when they’re working for you.” Johnathan: “Thank you, Will! I can’t tell you how worried I’ve been. This eases my mind greatly.” Of course, that’s not the word they’d likely be using. But the point is, everything has its place in context. Used this way, the racist terms are not glorified, nor gratuitous, but historically accurate. Sanitizing the work for modern sensibilities would simply ring hollow. Nor should you overuse them to show just how racist and mean the slave-holders are, as that would likewise ring hollow. The goal should be authenticity.  For more, read Quill and Ink

You should. It will represent your characters in a truthful and accurate light. Do you think portraying a racist slave owner from Civil War era would call his slaves (property) African Americans? It’d be unheard of, it be just as crazy for him to call them buy a non demeaning word/name than it would be for him to suddenly invite them to date his daughter and become his son in law. The 1960’s saw tons of racism. People attacking Dr. Martin Luther King weren’t calling him a “gentle, amazing smart human being”, they probably called him n****r, negro, monkey, boy or another other terribly demeaning words. Similarly, you’ve heard the tropes of older people who are less culturally sensitive call the Irish, “Micks”, Italians, “Whops”, Chinks, Japos, Gooks/Charlie right? Well let me tell you, no matter how many times you try to tell great uncle Hank, we can’t say faggots anymore, they’re going to call gays that. They’ll call your Hispanic friend a Spic and maybe even mutter the “n” word at a black man who’s cut him off in traffic. I can’t tell an accurate story about “my closeted racist Great Uncle Dumbledore” if I don’t portray him properly. However, you can’t use racist terms to describe your characters… i.e “Lejon Brames is a cotton picking, big lipped, black as tar ‘n*****’ who looks like a monkey”. THAT would be the type of racist writing we’d want to avoid:)

If this is a work of fiction, and set in the past, then you will probably (at certain times) have to resort to the slang and language and idioms that were used at the time. But — I would not usually expect to see much of it in the “narration” of the novel. Not usually. I would expect that each and every time a character in this story “speaks” — then words coming out of that character’s mouth would reflect that particular character. That is necessary. If the character is one who is alive in 1848, and from the deep south, I would expect them to speak the typical slang and usage and idioms and phrases and language that would have been used by that particular character during that time period, who is from that particular area or location. And, if that character is male, it might speak differently that the next character who speaks, because it is a female. If that character is a wealthy doctor who has bought lots of real estate, the language might be slightly different than the next character, who happens to be a poor, white blacksmith. So, the same is true when it comes to everything, even to the slang phrases they might use when referring to certain minorities, or to slaves. So, mostly I would expect to see those terms only inside of quotation marks: “Sure, I did,” Tom said. Didn’t mean ta’, I even tried darn hard to stop him, but there weren’t no way. There weren’t no way!” Tom gulped, looked down, exhausted. If it NOT dialogue, though: If it is a “third-person narrator,” it is just a voice. The voice that is telling us this story. In that case, it may never use those same slang terms, or language that we consider racist. Is that clear? If the one telling us the story (the narrator) is a first person narrator, then you need to decide WHO this character actually is, and all of their descriptions and story telling will reflect that. Hope that helps.

As a writer you have the freedom to use any terms you want in your writing. That doesn’t mean they will be tasteful, helpful, or non-offensive. It just comes down to how you use the term. For instance, you might use term as dialogue for a character who’s nature and personality causes them to use racist language. Another example is where you use the term as a quote from another person. You may also potentially use the term as a cultural moniker if you are writing directly to that culture. I’d research this completely before doing so. Where you will run into trouble is when you use a racist term as a description in the first person. In other words, you, the author, are describing another person with a racist term. As the writer you have the freedom (at least here in the U.S.) to use that language. Just remember… you don’t have the freedom to escape the consequences of what you write. Regardless of how you use a racist term in your writing, you are going to offend someone, somewhere. That is just the nature of controversy. Jon Pennington | The Working Writer

If you really don’t want the potential hassle of using words that are offensive today, you could consider researching archaic terms that are correct for the period but won’t elicit quite such a knee-jerk reaction nowadays. For instance (and I’m not totally sure this is idiomatic for the mid-19th-century American South, where I’m assuming your book might be set, but it certainly was in use in Britain in the period), blackamoor is unlikely to get people as hot under the collar as the N-word. But do the research really thoroughly if you pursue this route. Otherwise it’ll feel wrong to anyone who is familiar with the time and place of your story. Also, bear in mind: even a racist person in a racist era would not be constantly talking about how racist they were. It was probably pretty rare that a white slave-owner said “D’you know, Mary, I believe negroes are inferior to us white folk”. It was taken as read by his contemporaries that he believed this. That was just the way things were, for them. So - show us your characters and their society acting in racist ways, by all means, but try to avoid making racism overtly an issue for the characters, even if it is one for the readers. It was an unremarkable part of the characters’ world, not necessarily something to be commented on.

It all depends on your presentation. Do you make it seem glorified by a repetitive usage that doesn’t add anything to the story and through making the characters who use the term seem sympathetic because or in relation to their racism? Having sympathetic racist characters is fine. The majority of people you’d write about 300 years ago would be racist in some way or another, and yet they can still be compelling characters. It’s very likely that many of the communist revolutionaries were bigoted against women, even though they sparked radical changes that led to feminist prominence in many countries. It is not fine, however, to not treat their racism seriously and to allude to it just “being a part of them like bone and flesh”.

You’re allowed to use whatever terms you want; that’s what free speech means. The better question is whether the increased chance of causing offense is more or less significant than the increased accuracy, and I think that question can only be answered by someone who both would be the target of said racism, and enjoys historical fiction. If you’re looking to make money off the book, the decision also should consider the fact that some people will boycott it simply because it offends their sensibilities (whether the actual targets of the racism would be offended or not).
I’ve had the same internal struggle with some of my books that have taken place between 1880–1911. The times were deeply racist, and to pretend they weren’t is sanitizing history.

I think the racist characters should use racist terms. This will help develop the emotions and personalities of these characters. You need to just remember that some of these terms used to not be as offensive as they are considered now. If you are planning on writing a small section on a few facts about racism, it probably wouldn’t be the smartest idea to use racist terms. Some people might think that you yourself are racist, which I’m assuming you aren’t considering that you’re asking whether or not its okay to use racist terms in a novel about slavery. Slavery is a topic that will almost always come into contact with racism. It’s recommended that the narrative parts of the story aren’t too racist. For instance, use similes instead of metaphors. Instead of “The Chinese men were borrowed machinery”, Say “The Chinese men worked as if they were borrowed machinery” Hope this helped Good luck writing a novel!

Sure, assuming you’re in the USA, which you might not be, there is a certain freedom of expression and press, but that is gradually eroding and many are weak and breaking under the pressure of political correctness. But before I go off on that soapbox, as a rule, you can, for the sake of authenticity. No sense in saying stuff like “they called them really mean names!” unless you’re writing a children’s book. But your editor will tell you if you’ve crossed a line.

Yes, but. These days there is a growing sense of discomfort with ‘cultural appropriation’. If you’re a white person wanting to write a story about slavery, you might want to consider whether it’s a story you really are the best person to tell. This is a complex issue with passionate views on both sides, but I think it’s fair to say that African Americans have a point when they get bored of white people telling them about their own heritage - especially when, as so often, it turns into a story about a heroic white person who feels really bad about slavery. I’m not saying you shouldn’t write your story (and I’m making assumptions about your race that may be wrong, purely based on your question) but do it with care.

Allowed by whom? The government won’t stop you. The police won’t stop you. However, if you’re in school, the school or your specific class may have restrictions on the language used in assignments. And just as a side note, it’d be difficult to write a novel about slavery without dealing with race and racism. You certainly are not going to write, “The overseer shook his head in disgust at the slave and muttered, ‘You n-word.’” Sorry, but that just won’t work.

This is an intensely personal question that has more than one answer to consider besides freedom of the press. Consider your audience and their comfort level reading the language presented. Also consider yourself and your comfort level. If you aren't somewhat confident with your prose, your character won't come across as authentic. If the story is meant for a younger audience, I would leave the racist terms out of it. A story for adults can use them in proper context…but it might be a good idea to include a forward that states that this is a work of historical fiction and any racist views expressed by the characters are not shared by the author.

I have no right to grant anyone permission to do anything, but I will point out that one writer who was able to do it was Mark Twain. So I guess the obvious advice is, be as good as Mark Twain. And maybe the more subtle observation is that it’s likely acceptable to be accurate with the racist terms if the work is compelling and inspired.

As a reader, I would say “yes”. I think it’s an important part of conveying the reality of a society that accepts race-based slavery (I presume your setting is the antebellum US South, but I think the principle applies more generally). But please don’t use the terms just for shock value. Use them carefully, and with reason.

If you use it in such a way as to highlight that racist terms existed in a particular era (as they do now as well, unfortunately), then yes. The history of racism cannot be erased. However, I suggest that you don’t over-do it. Try to find the right balance. I also suggest you consult authors of historical fiction or other literary experts for advice.

Yes. Fiction is about characters. Making the reader love your character is good, making the reader hate your character is better, making the reader love and hate your character at the same time is divine. A good writer provokes a reader. You want the good, the evil, and the shameful. You need to make honest portrayals of those characters walking around in your head. And for the people who get offended with you, remember this saying “The name for people who think a writers values are the same as his characters values is stupid.” That’s a paraphrase, I couldn’t find the exact quote.

If you're aiming to be faithful to the history of the time period, then I'd say its unavoidable. Just don't overuse them, because that'll just get tiring and possibly verge on the exploitative.

What do you mean, are you allowed? We have freedom of speech. It may not be appropriate, but there’s no law that says you can’t. During the time of slavery, those terms were commonly used. They’re still used today in period pieces.
You may if it is a necessary element that add to your character and plot’s development, otherwise using derogatory or racist terms to simply rile up your readers may be deemed offensive.

You can do anything you'd like, but it pays to understand that there are consequences to face. Plenty of authors have done so with varying degrees of success. Think very carefully about your target audience in this case. Good luck!
